channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: UK Remote Perl Programmer
item.description: If you’re a talented Perl programmer with a passion for delivering high-quality work and a desire to learn and grow with a small and focused team, we want to hear from you! Our client's tech stack includes Debian, Apache, Nginx, Exim, Redis, MySQL/MariaDB, and PostgreSQL, as well as open-source tools written in Perl (DBIx and Plack), Bash, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl folks with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl Programmer with Rust Experience - UK Remote
item.description: Are you a talented Perl programmer with Rust experience looking to work for a cutting-edge enterprise tech publisher that’s at the forefront of the industry? Look no further than our client, a renowned publisher that provides unique news and stimulating perspectives on the enterprise tech that powers businesses across the globe.

item.title: Perl and Koha
item.description: August 14-18, 2023, Helsinki, Finland

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference 2023
item.description: July 11-13, 2023, Toronto, Canada

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Letter frequency
item.description: Just love the combination of Perl and Python. It reminds me when I used to contribute. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #216
item.description: First blog for the weekly challenge, well crafted. Well done.

item.title: Word Registration
item.description: Enjoy the Ruby implementation this week with great details. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #216
item.description: Loved the breakdown of complications in the task #2. Nice writings, I must admit.

item.title: Alphabetical exercises
item.description: Compact one-liner in Perl using the cool comnination of join,sort,uniq and split. Brilliant work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 216
item.description: True one-liner in Perl without any gimmicks. Just love it. Thanks for everything.

item.title: words, grep and letters!
item.description: Two choices, grep and regex one. You pick your favourite. Nice one.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 216: Registration Number
item.description: Just one this week making good use of Raku power as always. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 6^3
item.description: Find the best use of Perl magics as always. Highly recommended.

item.title: PWC216 - Word Stickers
item.description: Quite a detailed discussion of the solution, kudos for the efforts. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC216 - Registration Number
item.description: Too many questions but the solution is too simple. How? Do checkout the solution.

item.title: Car Nicknaming
item.description: New language features, never used before, is in action this week. Nice one, well done.

item.title: Sticky Numbers
item.description: Line by line description of the source code is very handy to follow the process. You even get the bonus link to official documentation. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 216
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Registration Number" and "Word Stickers" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 217
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Sorted Matrix" and "Max Number". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: PTS 2023 - Chad Granum
item.description: Bonus event report for all of us by Chad Granum.

item.title: PTS 2023 - Tux
item.description: Another great report by one of the most respectable participant. You really don't want to miss it.

item.title: SVG to PDF::Collage
item.description: Possible way to generate a template for PDF::Collage in a graphical-ish way.

item.title: How to Send and Receive Email with Perl
item.description: Simplest and easiest way to deal with email. Nice attempt.

item.title: SVG px conversion in Perl
item.description: Nice little example showing how to convert px to point in SVG.

item.title: Welcome new contributors with the first-timers-only tag
item.description: Nice attempt to encourage first-timers to contribute.

item.title: 2023 Stack Overflow Developer Survey
item.description: Please take the survey and share your Perl experience.

item.title: #616 - Camel in India
item.description:
Hi there,

When I say India, I mean Indian Subcontinent i.e. Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Srilanka. Having said, my prime concern is India right now. You must have realised the context of Camel by now. Today I would like to talk about the popularity of Perl in India. I remember when I left India in 2000, it was on the rise and that is how I got into Perl Programming. After moving to England, I noticed how frequent the Perl fans meetup and share ideas. I got the opportunity to attend some and realised how it can boost the popularity of the language and spread the positive word among newbies. Regular Perl Mongers meet also keep the subject live and active.

Ever since the COVID happened, all these in-person events stopped initially. But the good news is that we are getting back on track with the events like The Perl and Raku Conference 2023 and Perl and Koha Conference in Helsinki. I have decided to attend The Perl and Raku Conference in Canada. I have submitted talk proposal too, little late though. I am still waiting for the acceptance. The other conference is clashing with my planned visit to India unfortunately.

Going back to the main topic, I am wondering if we ever had any Perl Conference in India. I am aware of active Perl Mongers but never heard of their activities. In the year 2021, Will Braswell reached out to me with a proposal to do The Perl Conference in India. Because of COVID, we put it on hold then. At the time, we decided to do month long tour to cover major cities spending 2-3 days in each city. I suggested the best time would be August as I will have long summer break. We would definitely need sponsors, ideally if we do under the banner of The Perl Foundation then the reach would be even greater, in my humble opinion. The local Perl Mongers group can be handy in organising the event. I would be eager to know if any Perl Mongers group interested in these events. I would expect the groups down south would be more active as they are highly aware of technologies in general.

I just realised this is my 130th edition of the weekly newsletter. I also completed 5 years as co-editor of the weekly newsletter in this month.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter. Please do share your ideas and suggestions.
item.dc:subject: editorial
